galleries.name: Traces of Industry
galleries.description: Frédéric Bénard's Traces of Industry explores the slow transformation of industrial spaces — rusted surfaces, aging structures, and the quiet beauty of decay.

galleries.description: Frédéric Bénard's Red Cities traces the colour red across urban spaces — as signal, surface, and surprise — revealing rhythm and tension in the everyday built world.

galleries.name: Urban Patterns
galleries.description: Frédéric Bénard's Urban Patterns explores rhythm, repetition, and structure in city spaces — tiled façades, stacked windows, and quiet alignments in the everyday built world.

galleries.description: Frédéric Bénard's Minimal Structures captures quiet architectural forms and pared-down urban spaces — moments of light, geometry, and stillness across museums, courtyards, and back alleys.

galleries.name: Building Portraits
galleries.description: Buildings at rest — their façades, entrances, and back doors — each image a portrait of urban identity. Calm and composed, these exteriors invite us to pause and notice the character revealed in stillness.

galleries.name: Backlot Geometry
galleries.description: These photographs explore the unnoticed backlots of industry — loading docks, storage yards, and discarded remnants. Stripped of people, these spaces reveal a hidden order in their geometry, patterns, and residues, transforming the ordinary into something striking.

galleries.name: Walls
galleries.description: Walls, seen up close, become canvases — from bold graffiti to subtle traces of time. These images explore abstraction through color, texture, and the marks left on urban surfaces.
